ygData.subject: Re: How would novelty search best be applied to a virtual creature controller
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Peter, that s a good question and of course learning to control a virtual creature with novelty search is a complicated issue (and an appealing idea as

Hi Peter, that's a good question and of course learning to control a 
virtu=
al creature with novelty search is a complicated issue (and an 
appealing i=
dea as well). 

First, you have to deal with all the representational and p=
hysical 
issues outside of novelty search, like how many inputs, how many 
=
outputs, and whether the body itself is not physically flawed in 
some way =
(which is possible).  As you are experiencing, the 
inputs/outputs issue ca=
n be prohibitive even with feature 
selection.  It is also possible that Hy=
perNEAT could be useful 
because it does not care about the # inputs or out=
puts (and can 
potentially exploit geometric regularities), but configuring=
 the 
substrate then becomes the challenge.

Assuming all of that stuff is =
set up well with whatever system, then 
novelty search is a potentially win=
ning approach.  Yet as you point 
out there are some big questions there as=
 well.  In fact, we are 
currently trying to provide the best answers to th=
ese questions in 
ongoing research, but some general principles might help =
for now: 

First, the archive in novelty search does not not need to contai=
n 
every point ever visited.  Therefore, it tends to grow much slower 
than=
 the #of evaluations.  However, if it is indeed getting too big  
then it i=
s not unreasonable to collapse some of the archive points, 
although there =
is no standard method yet for how that should be 
done.  But we have reason=
 to believe there will be effective and 
simple ways to do that.

Second, t=
he issue of one individual looking different just because 
of a phase diffe=
rence in effectivley the same behavior is 
complicated.  For certain phase =
disaparities, the two individuals 
won't look all that different, but it is=
 true that at some 
disparity, they may look very different.  Yet it is not=
 clear 
whether that fact is actually problematic to the novelty search or =

not, because it would simply reward both types of behavior.  It is 
possib=
le that the phase difference is a result of some useful 
genotypic change, =
which could make it a stepping stone to something 
better.  Or, it is possi=
ble that it is superfluous information and 
simply takes some extra time ex=
ploring the area around the phase-
shifted individual.  So it is hard to sa=
y a priori whether it is a 
major concern.  We will have better answers to =
such questions as the 
technique is further explored.

However, I agree tha=
t it would be nice to be able to say the two 
phase-shifted individuals are=
 largely the same if that is indeed 
what you want to say.  And for that, y=
ou would need a pattern-
matching metric to compute behavioral distance, i.=
e. something more 
sophisiticated than simple Cartesian distance.  There ar=
e certainly 
such metrics available.  However, it's important to recognize =
that 
it is not evident at this point that ignoring the phase shift is 
act=
ually better than taking it into consideration, because taking it 
into con=
sideration just means adding more information to the novelty 
landscape.

S=
o overall I think novelty search is a very promising direction to 
go for s=
uch problems, but it is still in the realm of research (i.e. 
there is no e=
xisting precedent), so it will involve considerable 
trial and error to get=
 it right until all these issues are fleshed 
out more clearly.  Ultimately=
, though, if our hypothesis about 
novelty vs. fitness is correct, novelty =
search may turn out to be 
the *only* way to get certain highly complex typ=
es of behavior to 
evolve in some domains, which is a sobering thought.  Bu=
t if it is 
true, then there is not much to do other than try it.

ken

---=
 In neat@yahoogroups.com, "peterberrington" <peterberrington@...> 
wrote:
>=

> I've read Ken's latest paper on novelty search and its a 
fascinating
> =
new approach. For the past couple of months I've been working on
> virtual =
creature controllers; specifically I have a ragdoll rig 
which
> I've set u=
p in Breve Simulation Environment (available at
> http://spiderland.org )
>=
 This ragdoll is modelled after the one in Toribash, a free game 
which
> u=
ses the open dynamics engine for physics, like breve. 
> 
> So far a lot of=
 the results I've been having discouraging; as Ken
> points out early on in=
 his latest paper, trying to make a walking
> biped usually results in it f=
alling over perpetually. You can see 
some
> WIP videos at my youtube page =
here:
> http://www.youtube.com/user/thehaircrow
> 
> Ultimately, I would li=
ke to package AI's with the Toribash game so
> that they are fun to play ag=
ainst in single player- I think this 
goal
> is attainable despite being di=
fficult.
> Deception is a BIG problem here; if my fitness criteria is time
=
> integrated distance from a goal, it encourages the behaviour of the
> "To=
ri" balancing in a stable configuration forever, rather than
> walking, whi=
ch is what I'm trying to encourage. As there is 20 
joints
> in this rig, I=
 am providing joint position and velocity information
> for each joint, as =
well as a bias, a sine-wave, the x, y, and z
> components linear velocity i=
n the reference frame of the Tori's 
head,
> and finally 3 variables which =
correspond to the vertical, 
horizontal
> and forward orientation of the to=
ri's head with respect to world
> coordinates.  
> The current experimental=
 configuration I am started out as a "pure"
> ragdoll control where neural =
net outputs correspond directly joint
> velocity; a tanh activation functio=
n is used to allow positive and
> negative joint movement.
> I then remodel=
ed the experiment to perform as in the Toribash game;
> the net will receiv=
e inputs (and effect joint movements) only 
every 10
> time steps. More imp=
ortantly, I increased the amount of outputs 
from
> 20 (1 per joint) to 40,=
 in order to accomodate the 4 possible joint
> actions which can occur on a=
 turn: holding, relaxing, extending, 
and
> flexing. 
> 
> Starting with a =
fully connected net, that gives a staggeringly huge
> search space with ove=
r 1000 connections. Due to the implementation,
> its prohibitively slow to =
evolve large nets as the starting net can
> take up over 600mb of ram on th=
e heap. Realizing this was a bit
> ridiculous, I implemented feature select=
ion and phased pruning.
> However, even with this, deception seems to preve=
nt any useful
> behaviour; the Tori will always get stuck in ruts.
> 
> 
> =
I am using a python implementation of neat developed by Cesar Gomez
> under=
 the GPL, which is available at http://code.google.com/p/neat-
python/
> 
>=
 This implementation is a WIP and I've already done a lot of tests
> trying=
 to incorporate the linear genome encoding taken from the 
EANT
> method. I=
've also been trying to incorporate CMA-ES in order to
> optimize weights b=
ut I haven't had much success meshing this with 
the
> rest of the code yet=
.
> 
> Later today when I am home I will post my source files for anyone 
w=
ho
> wishes to experiment with virtual creature neuroevolution.
> 
> 
> 
> =
FINALLY, my question. The behaviour of a Tori is currently 
represented
> a=
s a list of 20 base 4 variables multiplied by the amount of time
> steps th=
e Tori is evaluated for. The novelty search method proposed
> for the 2d ma=
ze navigation is fairly simple; if theres a new ending
> point then 
> we a=
dd that point to a list of discovered behaviours. This works 
well
> (I ima=
gine) because a point isn't a lot of information to hold.
> 
> What I want =
to know is how I can compare the behaviour of 2 ragdoll
> controllers for n=
ovelty; is there any compact encoding that would
> work? Since it often tak=
es 25 000 seperate evaluations to get any
> useful behaviour out of this ri=
ght now, theres going to have to be
> some way to store 20k seperate behavi=
ours in some way that is fast 
and
> easy to compare; what if a Tori has id=
entical behaviour to another 
but
> does things a couple of time steps late=
r instead? Just comparing 
the
> two behaviours it would appear that they w=
ere 100% unique, yet a 
human
> observer would instantly notice the similar=
ity in how they act.
> 
> Any ideas?
>
